titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to Boston this morning with my brother— He went on to Medford— I settled accounts with Mr: Shaw, with Mr: P. C. Brooks, with Head and Amory— Partly with Mr: B. Hall— Called at the Bank of U.S.— Saw Mr: Sullivan, respecting the Medford Farm— Directors of Neponset Bridge met: could not form a quorum— Only Mr: Smith and Mr: Quincy there— Saw Mr: Boylston— Dined with Mr: Smith— Return’d to Whitcomb’s where I found my brother, and we came early home in the afternoon— Evening I began to read Smith’s translation of Thucydides.

2. Wrote all the morning. Analysis of the first collection Law, and arranging my accounts— Stroll’d in the afternoon with my gun— Wrote to my wife in the Evening.— My Mother took Susan to Milton. Mrs: Black here this afternoon— Mr: and Mrs: Quincy in the morning.

3. Went into Boston this morning, on horseback— Meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge— Agreed upon an assessment of 40 dollars to a share. The dividend for the first half year to be deducted.— Meeting of the Trustees of E. Hopkins’s donation— Transacted the usual business of the meeting; and chose Mr: Quincy, and Dr: Kirkland, to supply the vacancies of Deacon Phillips and Dr: Tappan, who died since the last annual meeting— Call’d at Mr: J. Gardner’s Office— Dined at R. G. Amory’s, with a company of gentlemen.— In the evening, I return’d to Quincy, excessively fatigued with my ride.

4. Spent this day principally, in recovering from the fatigue of yesterday— A Summer day— Miss H. Adams, and a Miss Bond dined with us— My brother went with Louisa Smith to Weymouth, this afternoon— I continue to analyze the Laws of the United States— Read some letters of Sevigné Vol: 5. and the prefaces of Smith’s Thucydides.
5. Part of the morning employed in grafting apple-trees and budding peach-trees— Dined with the Saturday club, at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— In the Evening read a couple of Canto’s in the Fairy Queen.

6. Heard Mr: Clap, for Mr: Whitney— Day rainy— Employed the leisure time in writing— Finished Analysis of the Laws U.S. 1st. Congress 1st: Session.— Boylston Adams spent the Evening with us. Read two Cantos in the legend of Sir Guyon, or Temperance in the Fairy Queen— The lake of Idleness.— The Bower of Bliss, and the Cave of Mammon are finely descriptive—especially the last.

7. Spent the day, in gardening; and in the Office; untill 5. in the afternoon; when I attended the town-meeting, held for the choice of a representative— Mr: Black had 43 votes and was chosen. Mr: Beale had 32. Mrs: Cranch here— In the Evening I read Cantos 8 and 9. Book 2, of the Faery Queen.

8. A Midsummer day— My Aunt Smith dined here— I pursue the analysis of the Laws in the forenoon, and in the afternoon read and write on various subjects— Bathed this forenoon; the first time this Season— Letters of Madame de Sevigné— Juvenal’s Satires, and the Faëry Queen—2d: Book Canto 10. The fabulous Chronicle of Briton Kings and Faery Emperors.

9. Cold weather returned. Walk’d up to my farm this forenoon. Received a letter from my wife, which I answered— Employed this afternoon upon Juvenal— Read also some letters of Madame de Sevigné; and in the Evening the 11th: and 12th: Cantos Book 2. of the Faery Queen.
10. Analyzing the second Collection Law—employed me all the morning; untill dinner time— In the afternoon I went out with my gun.— Begin to perceive a Want of exercise.

11. Finished reading the Laws of U.S. 1. Congress 2. Session— Walk’d over the hills before dinner— In the afternoon read Sevigné’s letters— Evening first 2 Cantos of Book 3—Faery Queen—The legend of Britomartis, or of Chastity.

12. Received this morning a letter from Coll: Bradford, requesting my attendance at 11. O’Clock at the Office of the Commissioners of Bankruptcy— On a meeting in the case of R. Child— My mother concluded to go into Boston with me— I attended at 11. Mr: Callender was there— Mr: Tudor was not— The meeting was to have been on Monday, and I was notified by mistake to attend this day— However Mr: W. Sullivan the Assignee was there; and I have him my opinion on the question he had to propose— Spent the remainder of the morning in procuring articles wanted, and to send to Washington. Dined at Mr: Foster’s with my mother; and early in the Evening we returned to Quincy.— Read Cantos 3. 4. Book 3. Faery Queen.

13. Heard Mr: Flint of Cohasset, who dined with us— As did T. Welsh junr: who came out from Boston; and returned in the Evening— Louisa returned from Weymouth— I am engaged in reading the Treaties of the U.S. published after the end of the 1st: Congress 2. Session— Evening. read Cantos 5. 6. of the Legend of Britomartis.

14. My Aunt Smith spent the day here— I employed it as usual; and in the afternoon wrote a letter to my wife— Attempted to read part of a dialogue of Lucian, in the Greek.— 6th: vol: of Sevignés letters; and Cantos 7. 8. of Book 3— Faery Queen— Wanting Exercise.

15. Continued writing all this morning— Still on the Treaties— Stroll’d an hour or two with my gun— Attempted a little more Greek—with Madame de Sevigné in the afternoon; and the Faery Queen in the Evening.

16. Finished the Treaties at the close of the 2. Session 1. Congress; and began with the Laws of 3. Session— Afternoon, read Madame de Sevigné— A little of Lucian— Evening 11. and 12 Canto’s Book 3. Faery Queen— The Masque of Cupid in Canto 11. full of Spenser’s Shadows— Judge Cushing and his Lady, dined here; and went on to Boston after dinner in the midst of a Storm— They are going to Portsmouth, where the Circuit Court opens this week.— Received a letter from my wife.

17. Morning employed upon U.S. Laws— Then a little of Lucian in Greek— I shall make small progress in this— Afternoon Madame de Sevigné— Finished 6. began 7. Vol:— Evening Canto 1. 2. of Book 4. of the Faery Queen— The legend of Cambell and Telamond; or of Friendship— The versification differs from that of the former books in the frequent use of double rhimes.— Mr: Greenleaf called on me this afternoon.

18. Went down to the Mount Wollaston farm, after my usual morning writing— Late home to dinner— Found Dr: Tufts and his lady there— My brother went to Braintree this afternoon— Letter from T. B. Johnson— Lucian— Sevigné, and Spenser in turn as usual.

19. Very busy all the morning, writing— Dined at Mr: Barrett’s with the club— When I came home this afternoon, found Mr: Hall and his son here— The Ladies at Mr: Black’s— Finished the first Volume of the U.S. Laws, and began upon the second.

20. Lazy Morning— Heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury, who dined with us.— I wrote a letter this afternoon to my wife.— Boylston Adams with us this Evening.— First appearance of the Peach-trees from the Stones I planted last September.

21. Had a bad Night— Rose very early this morning— Found a number more peach-trees just shooting up from the ground— Dexter made some of Forsyth’s composition which we are to try.— My reading and writing continues as usual. Ladies this afternoon at Mrs: Miller’s.— Canto’s 9. 10. Book 4. Faery Queen— The Palace of Venus described—including the imitation from the first lines of Lucretius.—

22. Pruned and trimm’d a number of trees in my father’s lower garden; and made the application of Forsyth’s composition. Went this afternoon with my mother, to Mrs: Cranch’s— In the field all the afternoon— Copious thunder shower in the Evening. Received a letter from my wife—finished the 4th: Book of the Faery Queen— I know not why it is called the Legend of Friendship; any more, than any other Book— The marriage of the Thames and Medway takes up almost the whole of the 11th: Canto.

23. Continued pruning trees, and applying Forsythe’s plaister— Mr: John Greenleaf and his Lady dined with us. William and Charlotte Welsh here this afternoon. He has just return’d from India, and is grown very tall. Wrote a letter this afternoon to T. B. Johnson— In the evening read the 1st: and 2d: Canto’s of the fifth book of Spenser’s Faery Queen— The legend of Arthegal, or of Justice— The 2d: Canto is remarkable by the passage where Arthegal contends with the Giant of Revolutionary Democracy— A Satire on the doctrines of Equality, hardly to be expected from that Age—

24. I headed down two small trees, by way of experiment. and trim’d a young peach-tree— Busily engaged. Finished 7th: Vol. Madame de Sevigne’s letters— Began the 8th: containing a collection from several persons, her correspondents— My Mother was unwell— But had a large Company of ladies at tea this afternoon.

25. Walk’d with my brother, up to his farm at Braintree— As we return’d, we saw Dr: Phips, and the foundation he is laying of a new house— We found on reaching home Mr: Isaac Smith and his Sister here— They dined, and are to pass the Night here— This afternoon I wrote to Mrs: Adams.

26. My brother went to Randolph this morning— I plaister’d the old Apple-tree in the lower-garden— The members of the fish-club, dined with us; and Dr: Tufts— W. S. Shaw, came out from Boston, with—John Welsh, and young Isaac Smith— Finish’d Analysis of 2d: Volume U.S. Laws—

27. Heard Mr: Ware— On purity of Heart— He dined with us— My Uncle Adams here in the Evening. I employed my time as usual— Analysing laws— Reading the letters to Madame de Sevigné— And in the Faery Queen.

28. Mr: Shaw return’d this Morning to Boston— Sent a letter by him— Plaister’d a decay’d apple-tree in the Garden, by way of experiment.— finished the 5th: Book of the Faery Queen; and the legend of Sir Arthegal or of Justice—the Revolution of the Netherlands, separated from Spain; and the League of against Henry II. of France, are pointed out in the latter Cantos.

29. Went to Boston this morning— Louisa Smith with me— Met Mr: H. G. Otis in the Street— He asked me to dine with him, which I did, with a large company. Attended the Meeting of the Academy; where the Officers for the year were re-elected, and some other business transacted— The meeting was quite full— Mr: Otis dined so late that I did not get away, untill near 7 in the Evening— Return’d then with Louisa to Quincy. Read the Cantos 1. and 2. of Book 6. Faery Queen— The legend of Sir Calidore, or of Courtesy.

30. General Election day— Judge Cushing and his Lady, dined here— Going to Boston, where the Circuit Court is to be held the 1st: of June— Mrs: Cranch with her School were here this afternoon.— I passed the day in my present customary occupations.

31. Received a letter from my wife, which I answered— Also, one from Mr: Dunlap of Alexandria, concerning Mrs. Hall’s business— Evening at my Uncle Adams’s— Sowed some of the seeds from Mr: W. Cunningham.— Mr: Briesler was here this morning.

Day. Rise between 6 and 7. With an interval of breakfast and half an hour’s walk round the garden, I am busied untill noon, on the analysis of the U.S. Laws— I have finished two volumes, and one Session of the third— That is about one third of the whole work— After finishing this, and a line or two of my Journal, I walk and tend the trees untill 1/2 past 1.— Dinner— After dinner— Read Sevigne’s letters, and lounge a couple of hours— Coffee, between 5 and 6.— Pass at leisure, untill 9— Light-supper And read 2. Cantos of the Faëry Queen— Bed between 10 and 11.
